Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Does the concept of a/an A-homomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Rank of an A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The rank of an A-module is defined based on the concept of linear independence within the module itself. It specifically involves finding the maximum number of linearly independent elements within the module. This definition focuses on the internal structure of the module and does not inherently require any mapping or relationship between different A-modules.

On the other hand, an A-homomorphism involves mappings between two A-modules. It is concerned with how elements of one A-module can be mapped to another while preserving the structure defined by the ring A. This concept is crucial when discussing properties that involve multiple modules, such as exact sequences or module isomorphisms.

Therefore, the definition of the rank of an A-module does not inherently require the concept of an A-homomorphism. The rank can be fully understood and defined without reference to mappings between different modules, focusing solely on properties within a single module.
